children.text: Clip: NAFTA Promotes US Trade with Mexico and Canada (1995)

NAFTA was originally negotiated under Republican President George H.W. Bush, the speaker in this section of the clip. However, the deal had yet to be approved by Congress when Bush was defeated in the 1992 election by Bill Clinton. The new Democratic president continued to advocate for NAFTAâ€™s passage in 1993. The trade deal faced opposition from both sides of the political aisle, but resistance was particularly strong among Democrats.

A tariff refers to a tax placed on imported goods entering a country. An import quota is a limit placed on a particular type of good (e.g. shoes, cars) from another country. NAFTA sought to ease trade between Canada, US, and Mexico by limiting, or even eliminating, tariffs and quotas.
